  • Formaldehyde - Fumigation of operating theater's, wards and labs.

questions.text: A truck driver came with painful genital ulcer and lymph nodes. H/O unprotected sex present. Choose the correct clinical condition: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chancroid

 

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by painful genital ulcers and painful lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes). The history of unprotected sexual intercourse and the clinical presentation of painful genital ulcers and painful lymph nodes strongly suggest chancroid.

 

  1. Painful genital ulcers: Chancroid typically presents with painful ulcers on the genitalia. These ulcers can be multiple and have irregular, undermined edges.
  2. Painful lymph nodes: The infection often leads to painful, swollen lymph nodes in the inguinal region, which can sometimes suppurate and form buboes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily, not typically associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Chancre: A chancre is a painless ulcer that is the primary lesion of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. It does not fit the description of painful ulcers and painful lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Herpes: Genital herpes, caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), presents with painful vesicles that evolve into ulcers. However, the presence of vesicles, rather than ulcers initially, distinguishes herpes from chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the parasites with their significance in pediatric infections: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

Explanation: 

 

The matching is based on epidemiological and clinical significance in pediatric populations:

 

A-1: Diphyllobothrium is most commonly acquired by children who swim in freshwater lakes where infected copepods are present

 

B-2: Paragonimus is a leading cause of hemoptysis in children in East Asian countries where raw/undercooked crustaceans are consumed

 

C-3: Brugia causes lymphatic filariasis but is a rare cause of elephantiasis in children compared to Wuchereria

 

D-4: Fasciola infection in children is primarily acquired through consumption of contaminated watercress

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Incorrectly associates Paragonimus with swimming-related infections

 

Option C: Wrongly suggests Diphyllobothrium is related to watercress consumption

 

Option D: Mismatches Brugia with swimming-related infections

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the epidemiological patterns and clinical presentations of various parasitic infections in pediatric populations, particularly focusing on mode of transmission and common presenting symptoms in different age groups and geographical regions.

questions.text: Function of IL-8 is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Chemotaxis

 

Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a cytokine that primarily functions as a chemokine. It plays a crucial role in the immune response by attracting and activating neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation through chemotaxis. This movement of neutrophils to the affected area helps in fighting infections effectively, as they are key cells in the innate immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fever: Fever is primarily induced by cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-alpha, not IL-8. These cytokines act on the hypothalamus to increase body temperature, which is a part of the systemic inflammatory response.

 

Option C. Lymphocyte proliferation: Lymphocyte proliferation is mainly associated with cytokines such as IL-2, which stimulates the growth of T cells. IL-8 does not play a direct role in lymphocyte proliferation.

 

Option D. TH1 activation: TH1 activation is driven by cytokines like IL-12 and IFN-gamma, which promote the differentiation of T-helper cells into the TH1 subtype. IL-8 is not involved in this process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary function of IL-8 is to induce chemotaxis, particularly attracting neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation.

questions.text: A child is presenting with fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, rash and spots in the oral cavity as shown in the given image, what is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

The clinical presentation of fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, rash, and characteristic spots in the oral cavity is indicative of measles. The spots shown in the image are Koplik spots, which are pathognomonic for measles.

 

Key Points about Measles:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by an RNA paramyxovirus.
  • Incubation Period: 10-14 days.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Koplik Spots: Small, white lesions with a red base typically found opposite the lower second molar.
    • Rash: Starts behind the ears (retroauricular) and spreads downwards.
    • Other Symptoms: Fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, and cough.

 

Common Complications:

 

  • Most Common: Serous otitis media.
  • Serious Complication: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a late and fatal complication.
  • Histopathology: Presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells in lymphoid tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chicken pox: Incorrect. Chicken pox (varicella) presents with a vesicular rash that typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the limbs and face. Oral lesions are not specific to chicken pox.

 

Option C. Mumps: Incorrect. Mumps typically presents with parotitis (swelling of the parotid glands) and may have associated fever and orchitis in males. Koplik spots are not a feature of mumps.

 

Option D. Rubella: Incorrect. Rubella presents with a fine, pink rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and limbs, but it does not present with Koplik spots. It is usually milder than measles and may have postauricular lymphadenopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Koplik spots, along with fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, and rash, is highly indicative of measles.

choices.text: Aplastic anemia - Patients with hereditary hemolytic anemia

questions.text: The following are parvovirus-related disease-population pairs. Identify the incorrect pair? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-erosive arthritis - Patients of SLE

 

Non-erosive arthritis is indeed a feature of parvovirus B19 infection, but it is not specifically associated with patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Instead, it can occur in otherwise healthy adults, often presenting as transient joint pain and swelling.

 

Other Options:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can cause several clinical syndromes depending on the patient's age and immune status:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia is typically seen in patients with hereditary hemolytic anemia, such as sickle cell disease, who develop transient aplastic crises due to parvovirus B19 infection. The virus targets erythroid progenitor cells, leading to a temporary cessation of red blood cell production.

 

Option B. Hydrops fetalis occurs in pregnant women when the fetus is infected with parvovirus B19. The infection can cause severe fetal anemia, leading to heart failure and generalized edema in the fetus.

 

Option C. Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or "slapped cheek" syndrome, commonly occurs in young children. It presents with a characteristic facial rash followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the trunk and limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvo virus infection -

 

Common symptoms of parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection include a mild nonspecific prodromal illness that may consist of fever (15-30% of patients), malaise, headache, myalgia, nausea, and rhinorrhea; typically beginning 5-7 days after initial infection

 

A diffuse maculopapular rash can appear 1-4 days later and fades to a lacy erythematous rash, which may be pruritic and may spread gradually toward the distal extremities. Most seropositive patients have no history of this classic biphasic illness. The clinical symptoms widely vary, and the classic "slapped cheek" rash is much more common in young children called as erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease,

 

Alternatively, parvovirus B19 infection may manifest with purpuric rash, erythema multiforme, or pruritus of the soles of the feet. Parvovirus B19 may cause a papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS), which manifests as an erythematous exanthem of the hands and feet with a distinct margin at the wrist and ankle joints.

 

Transient small joint arthropathy may be the main clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 in adults.

 

Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia is seen  in patients with immunosuppression.

 

Patients with severe anemia due to transient aplastic crisis (TAC) may present with pallor, fatigue, or signs of an aplastic crisis.

 

Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh colored when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: Causes strongyloidiasis, and the worms are much smaller and typically not as robust as those shown in the image.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Causes enterobiasis or pinworm infection. The worms are much smaller and thinner, typically only a few millimeters long.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection. The worms are also smaller and have a characteristic hook shape at one end.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is a large, cylindrical nematode parasite found in the human intestine, easily identifiable by its size, tapered ends, and characteristic pink to white color transition. The disease it causes, ascariasis, is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.

questions.text: Which of the following is an immunologically privileged site? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seminiferous tubule

 

The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site.

 

Sites with immune privilege are anatomical regions that are naturally less subject to immune responses than most other areas of the body. So, an allograft can be placed in these sites without endangering a rejection reaction.

 

Other examples:

 

  • Anterior chamber of the eye
  • Cornea
  • Testes
  • Brain except at area postrema where blood brain barrier is absent

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Area postrema: This region of the brain lacks the blood-brain barrier and is not considered an immunologically privileged site.

 

Option C. Optic nerve: While the optic nerve is part of the central nervous system, it is not classified as an immunologically privileged site like the brain or anterior chamber of the eye.

 

Option D. Loop of Henle: This structure is part of the kidney's nephron and is not considered an immunologically privileged site.

 

Educational Objective:


The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site, protecting developing sperm from immune system attack.

questions.text: Which type of PCR is suitable for identifying multiple causative agents? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiplex PCR    

 

Multiplex PCR is a technique that allows the simultaneous amplification of multiple target sequences in a single PCR reaction. This makes it particularly useful for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, such as when diagnosing conditions like diarrhea that can be caused by a variety of pathogens including viruses, bacteria, and fungi. Multiplex PCR uses multiple sets of primers in a single reaction mixture, each specific for a different target, allowing the detection of multiple organisms in one run.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conventional PCR: This method involves amplifying a single DNA target per reaction and is not designed to handle multiple targets simultaneously, making it less suitable for identifying multiple causative agents.

 

Option B. Real-time PCR: While real-time PCR can quantify DNA or RNA targets and is highly sensitive, it typically amplifies one target per reaction or a few targets in separate reactions rather than multiple agents in a single test.

 

Option D. Nested PCR: This technique is designed to increase the specificity of PCR by using two sets of primers in two successive runs, but it is not intended for simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens. It is primarily used to reduce non-specific binding and enhance detection sensitivity for a specific target.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiplex PCR is the best choice for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, making it efficient and comprehensive for diagnosing conditions caused by various pathogens.

choices.text: Cell mediated and antibody mediated response

questions.text: Type IV hypersensitivity is due to: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cell mediated response

 

A Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by T cells that provoke an inflammatory reaction against exogenous or endogenous antigens. In certain situations, other cells, such as monocytes, eosinophils, and neutrophils, can be involved. After antigen exposure, an initial local immune and inflammatory response occurs that attracts leukocytes. The antigen engulfed by the macrophages and monocytes is presented to T cells, which then becomes sensitized and activated. These cells then release cytokines and chemokines, which can cause tissue damage and may result in illnesses. It is considered a delayed hypersensitivity reaction because it usually occurs more than 12 hours after exposure to the allergen, with a maximal reaction time between 48 and 72 hours.

 

Examples of illnesses resulting from type IV hypersensitivity reactions include contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell mediated and antibody mediated response: This is not correct for Type IV hypersensitivity, which is exclusively cell-mediated and does not involve antibodies.

 

Option C. Antibody mediated response: This describes Type I, II, and III hypersensitivities, which involve IgE, IgG, or IgM antibodies, respectively. Type IV is exclusively cell-mediated.

 

Option D. Innate response: While the innate immune response involves cells like macrophages and neutrophils, Type IV hypersensitivity specifically involves the adaptive immune system, particularly T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IV hypersensitivity is a cell-mediated response primarily involving T cells and other immune cells, leading to delayed-type reactions such as contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

The four types of hypersensitivity are:

 

  1. Type I: reaction mediated by IgE antibodies
  2. Type II: cytotoxic reaction mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies
  3. Type III: reaction mediated by immune complexes
  4. Type IV: delayed reaction mediated by cellular response

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue

 

Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue is the xenodiagnostic method among the given options.

 

Xeno-diagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.

 

Uses -

 

  1. Diagnosis of Chagas disease. Laboratory bred Reduviid bugs (vector/ foreign host) are allowed to feed on the suspected patients (original host). After 4-5 weeks, the feces of the bugs are microscopically examined for amastigote forms of Trypanosoma cruzi (pathogen).
  2. Identification of dengue virus - Intrathoracic inoculation of the mosquitoes (vector) with viruses (pathogen). The virus multiplies in different organs of the mosquito (Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus, and Toxorhynchites) and can be easily demonstrated.
  3. In Trichinella spirals infection, muscle biopsy bits from suspected patients are fed to laboratory rats (vector) for T. spiralis. The larvae of T. spiralis can be demonstrated in the muscles of the infected lab rats.

 

Advantage of xeno-diagnosis: It is useful in cases where a direct microscopic diagnosis is difficult due to the low count of pathogens in the blood of the host/patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC: This is not a xenodiagnostic method but a laboratory assay to test the enterotoxigenicity of ETEC (Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli).

 

Option C. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: This method is not classified as xenodiagnosis; it is a form of animal inoculation for diagnosing Leishmaniasis.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: This is the Elek test for diphtheria toxin production and is not a xenodiagnostic method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to detect the presence of pathogens by allowing the vector to feed on or be injected with the patient's tissue, then examining the vector for the pathogen. Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue is a classic example of this diagnostic method.

choices.text: Giemsa stain for blood smear, Plasmodium

questions.text: A 45-year-old wildlife photographer presents with fever, weight loss, and pancytopenia after returning from Central Africa. His bone marrow examination shows macrophages containing intracellular organisms with a round to oval morphology. Which diagnostic test would be most appropriate? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urinary antigen test, Histoplasma

 

The clinical presentation with the bone marrow showing intracellular organisms in macrophages from a patient returning from Central Africa is suggestive of disseminated histoplasmosis. The urinary antigen test for Histoplasma is highly sensitive (>90%) for diagnosing disseminated disease, especially in immunocompetent patients with acute pulmonary histoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal culture, Histoplasma: While this is the gold standard, cultures can take up to 4 weeks and may not be practical for immediate management decisions.

 

Option B. rk39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis: Though Leishmania can present similarly, it's less common in Central Africa, and the organisms typically show characteristic kinetoplast (double-dot appearance) which isn't mentioned in this case.

 

Option D. Giemsa stain for blood smear, Plasmodium: Malaria parasites are typically seen within red blood cells, not macrophages, making this an inappropriate choice given the bone marrow findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In disseminated histoplasmosis, the urinary antigen test provides rapid results with high sensitivity, particularly useful in:

  • Acute cases requiring prompt treatment initiation
  • Situations where culture confirmation would delay therapy
  • Cases with characteristic bone marrow findings showing intracellular organisms
  • Patients with exposure history in endemic regions The test detects Histoplasma polysaccharide antigen and can also be used to monitor treatment response.

questions.text: β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucormycosis

 

The β 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis.

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (Mucor, Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect BDG (in ng/ml) by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes.

 

Level of ≥80 pg/mL is considered a positive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: The β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose candidiasis as Candida species produce BDG.

 

Option B. Aspergillosis: The assay is also effective for diagnosing aspergillosis since Aspergillus species produce BDG.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis pneumonia: Pneumocystis jirovecii, the causative agent of Pneumocystis pneumonia, produces BDG, making the assay useful for its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The β 1-3 glucan assay is not effective for diagnosing mucormycosis because the fungi causing mucormycosis (Mucor, Rhizopus) either lack (1-3)-β-D-glucan or produce it at minimal levels. This assay is useful for diagnosing fungal infections like candidiasis, aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis pneumonia which involve fungi that produce significant levels of BDG.

questions.text: A veterinarian developed an ulcer with central black eschar over the forearm as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacillus anthracis

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax which is caused by Bacillus anthracis.

 

Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:

 

  • ﻿﻿Cutaneous Anthrax (hide porter's disease)- Black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring around the eschar, is referred to as a malignant pustule.
  • ﻿﻿Pulmonary Anthrax (Wool sorter's disease) - Hemorrhagic pneumonia.
  • ﻿﻿Intestinal Anthrax- Hemorrhagic diarrhoea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in wounds and burns, often producing a greenish pus but not typically associated with black eschars.

 

Option B. Yersinia pestis: Causes bubonic plague, associated with swollen and painful lymph nodes (buboes) rather than black eschars.

 

Option D. Francisella tularensis: Causes tularemia, which can present with ulcers at the infection site but lacks the characteristic black eschar of anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous anthrax is characterized by the initial appearance of a small pimple that quickly turns into a painless ulcer with a necrotic (black) eschar at the center. This presentation is typical for individuals who have been in contact with infected animals or animal products, which is common in the veterinary profession.

 

Additional Information

 

Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax. He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. Hence, he is Known as the Father of Bacteriology.

 

Koch's postulates, which link specific microorganisms to specific diseases, state that the microorganism must be:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Found in abundance in diseased organisms, but not in healthy organisms.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Re-isolated from the diseased experimental host and identical to the original specific causative agent

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ancylostoma duodenale

 

The egg in the given picture is that of a hookworm. Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus (new world hookworm) are identical.

 

The eggs of hookworm are:

 

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless
  • Not bile stained
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

 

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are round to oval, thick-shelled, and often bile-stained. They have a rough, mammillated outer layer.

 

Option B. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis eggs are usually not seen in stool samples because they hatch within the intestine. The diagnostic stage is the rhabditiform larva found in the stool.

 

Option C. Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm): Enterobius vermicularis eggs are oval, flattened on one side, and have a thick, colorless shell. They are typically detected using the "Scotch tape" method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hookworm eggs are oval, colorless, thin-shelled, and contain 4 to 8 blastomeres. These eggs are not bile-stained and have a clear space between the ovum and the eggshell.

questions.text: A patient presented with retro-orbital pain and rash since the 5 days. Most appropriate test to be done now is:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody detection by ELISA

 

When diagnosing dengue fever, the timing of the test is crucial. Dengue virus infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus, its RNA, or its antigens, as well as by detecting antibodies against the virus.

 

NS1 Ag ELISA (Option A) and Dengue RNA by PCR (Option B) are methods used to detect the presence of the dengue virus or its antigens in the early stages of the infection, typically within the first 1-5 days of symptom onset. This is because the viral load and antigen levels are highest during this period.

 

Antibody detection by ELISA (Option C) becomes more appropriate after the initial phase of infection, typically after 5-7 days. At this point, the patient's immune system has started producing antibodies (IgM and IgG) against the virus, which can be detected using ELISA.

 

Viral culture (Option D), while definitive, is not typically used in routine clinical practice due to its complexity, cost, and time requirements.

 

Since the patient has been symptomatic for 5 days, it is likely that antibodies have begun to be produced. Therefore, the most appropriate test at this stage is the detection of antibodies by ELISA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NS1 Ag ELISA: This test is most effective within the first 1-5 days of infection when the NS1 antigen is present in the blood. After this period, its sensitivity decreases.

 

Option B. Dengue RNA by PCR: This test is also most effective within the first 1-5 days of infection for detecting the viral RNA. After this period, the viral load decreases, making the test less effective.

 

Option D. Viral culture: This method is not commonly used in routine practice due to its complexity and time-consuming nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with dengue symptoms for more than 5 days, the most appropriate diagnostic test is antibody detection by ELISA, as antibodies are typically present after 5-7 days of infection.
